node.title: Those Loud and Polluting Leaf Blowers
node.description: Readers mostly excoriate and urge alternatives to what one calls “these obnoxious, deafening, exhaust-spewing machines.” Also: The metaverse; signs of concern.
node.content: ["To the Editor:", "Re \u201cThe First Thing We Do, Let\u2019s Kill All the Leaf Blowers,\u201d by Margaret Renkl (Opinion guest essay, Oct. 26):", "Our town of Winnetka, Ill., has had a summer-month ban on gas-powered leaf blowers for many years that has been largely ignored by landscapers. This past spring, local residents decided to change that. By June, our police department had secured voluntary pledges from 35 landscapers to obey the ban. The pledge wasn\u2019t perfect, but our town was quieter and the air cleaner than it\u2019s been for years.", "When people learn about how these antiquated machines harm people and the planet, there\u2019s a strong pull to do the right thing.", "King PoorWinnetka, Ill.", "To the Editor:", "As someone who has loathed these obnoxious, deafening, exhaust-spewing machines for years, all I can say \u2014 loudly, because of the noise \u2014 is: Yes!", "I would add just one thing to Margaret Renkl\u2019s case for banning these irritants. There\u2019s an alternative to the leaf blower that is cheap, readily available and virtually silent.", "It\u2019s called a rake.", "Mark RemyPortland, Ore.", "To the Editor:", "I spent a recent autumn Sunday wandering around parts of Brooklyn. I marveled at the ability to hear my own footfalls on the side streets, thinking how much quieter it was in the big city than in my own small town. It was then that I realized the difference: No one was blasting those infernal leaf blowers! It was such a joy to be able to hear yourself think.", "Rande BeidelRutherford, N.J.", "To the Editor:", "Margaret Renkl doesn\u2019t like leaf blowers, nor does she seem to appreciate the hard work the landscape industry does daily to care for our nation\u2019s green infrastructure. But rest assured that the landscape industry is making the transition to zero-emissions equipment as soon as it is feasible for commercial use.", "In addition, new technologies like smart controllers for irrigation, robotic and battery-powered mowers, drones and soil sensors are advancing rapidly and are making the care of your yards, parks and campuses even more eco-friendly each day.", "Britt WoodFairfax, Va.The writer is chief executive of the National Association of Landscape Professionals.", "To the Editor:", "Margaret Renkl omitted one item from her long list of gas-powered leaf blower ills: the sorry burden they place on the low-wage workers most affected by the noise, vibration and pollution emitted by these destructive machines.", "Paul OppenheimPownal, Maine", "To the Editor:", "It is not only in the autumn that we are subjected to horrific noise and air pollution, but also during the summer months when the roars of gas-driven lawn mowers and leaf blowers offensively punctuate the lazy, hazy days. And what about the winter months with the blaring gas-powered snow blowers? All the noise is enough to raise one\u2019s blood pressure.", "Until lawmakers find a way to ban these health and environmental menaces, I will wear my earphones to listen to some calming music.", "Frances R. CurcioStaten Island", "To the Editor:", "I\u2019ll give you my leaf blower when you pry it from my cold, dead hands.", "William BlalockDeland, Fla.", "To the Editor:", "Re \u201cMetaverse? Are You Kidding Me?!,\u201d by Charles M. Blow (column, Nov. 1):", "Mark Zuckerberg\u2019s suggestion that we should now spend our time in a virtual world is most timely, if by \u201ctimely\u201d we mean: at the worst possible moment.", "Our real world is creating diseases like Covid-19. In our real world, what we used to consider rare disasters are now frequent disasters. Right now, we must face our actual world and decide how to deal with it. But our Facebook prophet says: No! It\u2019s time to escape.", "I do not know whether all the ideas about this virtual world are new, but I imagine that some of them were cribbed from a memo that began, \u201cDear Nero, here\u2019s what to do while Rome burns.\u201d", "Our greatest artists, over hundreds of years, have struggled to convey the most frightening image of the horrors of Hell. This imagined virtual world in which we will \u201csocialize,\u201d buy and play, where we will have nothing to fear but hackers and the effects of Facebook\u2019s moderation and A.I., is likely to trump them all.", "Tobias D. RobisonPrinceton, N.J.", "\u200bTo the Editor:", "\u200bDear Mr. Blow: \u200b\u200bThank you for helping me continue disengaging from the social media world.", "Jacqueline Nowak\u200bDayton, Ohio", "To the Editor:", "In \u201cThe Curious, Persistent Power of a Yard Sign That Went Viral\u201d (Critic\u2019s Notebook, front page, Oct. 31), Amanda Hess writes, \u201cWith its exhaustive list of allied issues,\u201d the \u201cIn This House\u201d sign \u201cdiffuses the owner\u2019s perceived responsibility to engage in any particular movement.\u201d", "That seems unfair. I also think there is way more behind these signs than liberal white women in the midst of a crisis both political and cultural. The sign owners are better thought of as concerned citizens, cognizant and outraged at the economic, social and civic ills in our country.", "To me these signs are a lovely antidote to the reasons they exist \u2014 the increase in overt racism, misogyny, science denial and a disregard of the truth.", "And the sign\u2019s kicker \u2014 what Ms. Hess calls the \u201csanctimonious final line\u201d \u2014 \u201cKindness Is Everything\u201d? Bring it on!", "Kathy LottyFairfield, Conn."]
